facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 431 of 1963 appealed from judgment and decree dated May 21, 1958 of Punjab High Court in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 263-P of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 431 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 21, 1958 of the Punjab High Court in Civil Regular Second Appeal No. 263-P of 1952.

facts.text: Mst. Raj Kaur was in possession of 851 kanals 18 marlas of land in village Dhaipai in former State of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the contentions it is necessary to set out the relevant facts which are no longer in dispute. Mst. Raj Kaur was in possession of 851 kanals 18 marlas of land situate in village Dhaipai in the former State of Faridkot.

facts.text: Out of the land, 481 kanals 7 marlas was in possession of Mst. Raj Kaur as occupancy tenant, landlord being Raja of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this land 481 kanals 7 marlas was in her possession as occupancy tenant, the landlord being the Raja of Faridkot while the remaining land was held by Smt. Raj Kaur as Adna Malik, the Aala malik again being the said Raja of Faridkot.

facts.text: Remaining land held by Smt. Raj Kaur as Adna Malik, Aala Malik Raja of Faridkot.

anchor.surface_text: while the remaining land was held by Smt. Raj Kaur as Adna Malik, the Aala malik again being the said Raja of Faridkot. In Samvat 1953 (A.D.1896) Smt. Raj Kaur who had two daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur, adopted the formers son Bakshi Singh and put him in possession of the whole of the land.

facts.text: In Samvat 1953 A.D.1896, Smt. Raj Kaur adopted Prem Kaur's son Bakshi Singh and put him in possession of whole land.

anchor.surface_text: In Samvat 1953 (A.D.1896) Smt. Raj Kaur who had two daughters Prem Kaur and Mahan Kaur, adopted the formers son Bakshi Singh and put him in possession of the whole of the land.

facts.text: Bakshi Singh transferred part of land to Pratap Singh, second son of Mahan Kaur, respondent No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: Bakshi Singh transferred part of the land to Pratap Singh, second son of Mahan Kaur, who is respondent No. 2 in the appeal. Mahan Kaur had one more son Lal Singh and he is respondent No. 1 in this appeal.

facts.text: In 1915, Raja of Faridkot filed suit against Bakshi Singh and Raj Kaur for declaration that adoption of Bakshi Singh invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1915 the Raja of Faridkot filed a suit against Bakshi Singh and Raj Kaur in the court of Sub-Judge, Faridkot for a declaration that the adoption of Bakshi Singh was invalid.

facts.text: Suit decreed on February 9, 1916.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was decreed on February 9, 1916. Raj Kaur died on August 14, 1930.

facts.text: Raj Kaur died on August 14, 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Raj Kaur died on August 14, 1930. On February 19, 1934 the Raja filed two suits against Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh for possession of the aforementioned lands,

facts.text: On February 19, 1934, Raja filed two suits against Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh for possession of lands.

anchor.surface_text: On February 19, 1934 the Raja filed two suits against Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh for possession of the aforementioned lands, one pertaining to the land of which Raj Kaur was occupancy tenant and the other for that of the land of which she was Adna malik.

facts.text: Suits decreed on March 12, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: These suits were decreed on March 12, 1938 and in execution of the decrees obtained in these suits the Raja took possession of the entire land in October 1938.

facts.text: Raja took possession of entire land in October 1938.

anchor.surface_text: and in execution of the decrees obtained in these suits the Raja took possession of the entire land in October 1938. On April 7, 1948 he sold the entire land along with some other land to one Kehar Singh for Rs. 84,357-5-0.

facts.text: On April 7, 1948, Raja sold entire land along with some other land to Kehar Singh for Rs. 84,357-5-0.

anchor.surface_text: On April 7, 1948 he sold the entire land along with some other land to one Kehar Singh for Rs. 84,357-5-0. Thereupon Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh. who are the appellants before us, filed a suit for pre-emption of the land against Kehar Singh and obtained a decree in their favour.

facts.text: Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh filed pre-emption suit against Kehar Singh and obtained decree.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Gurbinder Singh and Balbinder Singh. who are the appellants before us, filed a suit for pre-emption of the land against Kehar Singh and obtained a decree in their favour. In execution of that decree they got possession of the land on June 22, 1950.

facts.text: Appellants got possession of land on June 22, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In execution of that decree they got possession of the land on June 22, 1950. On October 20, 1948 Mst. Prem Kaur instituted a suit for possession of the entire land on the ground that she was the legal heir of Raj Kaur against Kehar Singh and the Raja of Faridkot.

facts.text: On October 20, 1948, Mst. Prem Kaur instituted suit for possession as legal heir of Raj Kaur against Kehar Singh and Raja.

anchor.surface_text: On October 20, 1948 Mst. Prem Kaur instituted a suit for possession of the entire land on the ground that she was the legal heir of Raj Kaur against Kehar Singh and the Raja of Faridkot. Later she impleaded the appellants as defendants to that suit and discharged the Raja of Faridkot.

facts.text: On February 17, 1950, Lal Singh filed suit for possession against Raja, Kehar Singh, joined Prem Kaur and Pratap Singh as defendants, later Pratap transposed as plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On February 17, 1950, Lal Singh, respondent No. 1, filed a suit for possession of the entire land against the Raja of Faridkot and Kehar Singh. To that suit he joined Prem Kaur and Pratap Singh as defendants. Later, however, Pratap Singh was transposed as a plaintiff.

facts.text: Both suits of Prem Kaur and respondents consolidated and tried together.

anchor.surface_text: Both the suits were consolidated and were tried together. The suit of Prem Kaur was dismissed by the trial court but that of the respondents was decreed to the extent of half share in the property.

facts.text: Prem Kaur's suit dismissed by trial court, respondents' suit decreed to half share.

anchor.surface_text: The suit of Prem Kaur was dismissed by the trial court but that of the respondents was decreed to the extent of half share in the property. Prem Kaur and the appellants preferred appeals before the District Court but that court dismissed both the appeals.

facts.text: District Court dismissed appeals of Prem Kaur and appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Prem Kaur and the appellants preferred appeals before the District Court but that court dismissed both the appeals. A second appeal was taken by the appellants as well as by Prem Kaur to the High Court and cross-objections were preferred by the respondents.

facts.text: High Court dismissed second appeals and cross-objections.

anchor.surface_text: A second appeal was taken by the appellants as well as by Prem Kaur to the High Court and cross-objections were preferred by the respondents. The High Court dismissed these appeals as well as the cross-objections.

facts.text: Mahan Kaur died on July 13, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession.

facts.text: Relevant facts are no longer in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the contentions it is necessary to set out the relevant facts which are no longer in dispute.

facts.text: Raja's possession became adverse to Prem Kaur and respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh from October 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.

facts.text: Appellants' suit for possession is not barred by limitation under Article 144 as adverse possession less than 12 years from October 1938 to suit date.

anchor.surface_text: The sum total of the adverse possession of these three persons at the date of the respondents suit would, however, be less than 12 years and so the respondents suit could not be said to be barred by art. 144 if the starting point of limitation is taken to be some day in October, 1938.

issues.text: whether the suit for possession instituted by the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh is within time

anchor.surface_text: The only question for consideration in this appeal by certificate from the High Court of Punjab is whether the suit for possession instituted by the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh is within time.

issues.text: whether art. 142 of the Limitation Act applies to the suit

anchor.surface_text: In order that art. 142 is attracted the plaintiff must initially have been in possession of the property and should have been dispossessed by the defendant or someone through whom the defendants claim or alternatively the plaintiff should have discontinued possession. It is not the plaintiffs case that Lal Singh ever was in possession of the property. It is true that Pratap Singh was in possession of part of the property--which particular part we do not know--by reason of a transfer thereof in his favour by Bakshi Singh. In the present suit both Lal Singh and Pratap Singh assert their claim to property by succession in accordance with the rules contained in the dastur ul amal whereas the possession of Pratap Singh for some time was under a different title altogether. So far as the present suit is concerned it must, therefore, be said that the plaintiffs--respondents were never in possession as heirs of Raj Kaur and consequently art. 142 would not be attracted to their suit.

issues.text: whether under art. 144 the suit is barred by time

anchor.surface_text: It is in these circumstances that we have to consider whether under art. 144 the suit is barred by time. The starting point of limitation set out in col. 3 of art. 144 is as follows When the possession of the defendant becomes adverse to the plaintiff.

issues.text: whether the adverse possession of Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh can be tacked on to the adverse possession of the Raja and those who claim through him

arguments.claim: Possession of Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh can be tacked to adverse possession of Raja and those claiming through him, barring suit by limitation

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Tarachand Brijmohanlal, however, advanced an interesting argument to the effect that if persons entitled to immediate possession of land are somehow kept out of possession may be by different trespassers for a period of 12 years or over, their suit will be barred by time.

arguments.court_reasoning: Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh were independent trespassers; no jural relationship to Raja who trespassed on them; art. 144 allows tacking only through those from whom defendant derives title

arguments.claim: Ramayya v. Kotamma supports tacking possession across successive trespassers where owner out of possession over 12 years

anchor.surface_text: In support of the contention reliance is placed by learned counsel on the decision in Ramayya v. Kotamma 1 . In order to appreciate what was decided in that case a brief resume of the facts of that case is necessary.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as that case under art. 142 with continuity via heir; here art. 144 and independent trespassers

arguments.claim: Under art. 144 and s. 2 definition of defendant, tacking prior adverse possession only possible through persons from or through whom defendant derives liability, not independent trespassers
Doctrine of independent trespassers prevents tacking possession of Bakshi Singh and Pratap Singh to Raja's possession

anchor.surface_text: Further the doctrine of independent trespassers will come in only when the second man trespasses upon the possession of the first or the first man abandons possession. Where it applies the principle laid down in Agency Cos case-would apply and preclude the tacking of possession of successive trespassers.

holdings.text: the plaintiffs--respondents were never in possession as heirs of Raj Kaur and consequently art. 142 would not be attracted to their suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the present suit both Lal Singh and Pratap Singh assert their claim to property by succession in accordance with the rules contained in the dastur ul amal whereas the possession of Pratap Singh for some time was under a different title altogether. So far as the present suit is concerned it must, therefore, be said that the plaintiffs--respondents were never in possession as heirs of Raj Kaur and consequently art. 142 would not be attracted to their suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiffs claim by succession as heirs; prior possession of Pratap Singh was under different title from transfer by Bakshi Singh, not as heir; Lal Singh never in possession.

holdings.text: the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Raja obtained possession under decree but as trespasser vis-a-vis true owners (heirs); adverse from date of taking possession in Oct 1938 after Mahan Kaur's death.

holdings.text: The sum total of the adverse possession of these three persons [Raja, Kehar Singh, appellants] at the date of the respondents suit would, however, be less than 12 years and so the respondents suit could not be said to be barred by art. 144 if the starting point of limitation is taken to be some day in October, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The sum total of the adverse possession of these three persons at the date of the respondents suit would, however, be less than 12 years and so the respondents suit could not be said to be barred by art. 144 if the starting point of limitation is taken to be some day in October, 1938.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation under art. 144 starts when defendant's possession becomes adverse (Oct 1938); tacking allowed among Raja, transferee Kehar Singh, pre-emptors (appellants) as privity exists; total period <12 years to suit date.

holdings.text: the defendant is not entitled to tack on the previous possession of [independent trespasser] to his own possession.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 144 col.3 starts limitation when 'defendant's' possession adverse; s.2 def. 'defendant' includes those through whom defendant derives liability (jural relationship/privity required); no privity between independent trespassers (Bakshi Singh/Pratap Singh and Raja).

holdings.text: the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the courts below.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Not barred under art.142 (no prior possession as heirs) or art.144 (<12 yrs adverse possession from Oct 1938 by defendants in privity; no tacking independent trespassers' prior possession).

anchor.surface_text: Ramayya v. Kotamma 1

precedents.cited_proposition: adverse possession of successive trespassers can be tacked together to bar suit by true owner if continuous exclusion over 12 years under Art 142

anchor.surface_text: Mohendra Nath v. Shamsunnessa 3 held that time begins to run against the last full owner if he himself was dispossessed

precedents.cited_proposition: time begins to run against the last full owner if dispossessed and does not stop on succession by heir
precedents.cited_holding: operation of the law of limitation would not be arrested by the fact that on his death he was succeeded by his widow, daughter or mother

anchor.surface_text: Agency Co. v. Short that in cases of successive trespassers limitation ceases to run against the lawful owner of the land after an intruder has relinquished his possession

precedents.cited_proposition: upon abandonment by a trespasser without perfecting title, limitation clock resets for the true owner against successive trespassers
precedents.cited_holding: The possession of the intruder, ineffectual for the purpose of transferring title, ceases upon its abandonment to be effectual for any purpose

anchor.surface_text: Willis v. Earl Howe 2 and a passage in Dart on Vendors and Purchasers, Vol. 17th ed. p. 474 held that the suit was barred by time

precedents.cited_proposition: continuity of possession where presumptive heir continues possession after death of trespasser

anchor.surface_text: Rajagopala Naidu v. Ramasubramania Ayyar 1 . Further the doctrine of independent trespassers will come in only when the second man trespasses upon the possession of the first

precedents.cited_proposition: doctrine of independent trespassers applies only when second trespasser enters on first's possession or first abandons

anchor.surface_text: In the present suit both Lal Singh and Pratap Singh assert their claim to property by succession in accordance with the rules contained in the dastur ul amal whereas the possession of Pratap Singh for some time was under a different title altogether. So far as the present suit is concerned it must, therefore, be said that the plaintiffs--respondents were never in possession as heirs of Raj Kaur and consequently art. 142 would not be attracted to their suit.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the companyrts below.

anchor.surface_text: Mahan Kaur had in fact died on July 13, 1938, i.e. before the Raja obtained possession. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the possession of the Raja became adverse to Prem Kaur and to the respondents Lal Singh and Pratap Singh as from October, 1938.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the companyrts below.

anchor.surface_text: The sum total of the adverse possession of these three persons at the date of the respondents suit would, however, be less than 12 years and so the respondents suit could not be said to be barred by art. 144 if the starting point of limitation is taken to be some day in October, 1938.
In our opinion, therefore, the respondents suit is within time and has been rightly decreed by the companyrts below.
